awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Maternal Transitions in a Mouth-Brooding Cichlid
awd_abstract_narration:
Maternal care has evolved in many animals, yet most research on the underlying neural mechanisms has been carried out only in mammals. This project capitalizes on that rich body of research to study maternal mouth-brooding in the cichlid fish Astatotilapia burtoni. This species offers an independently-evolved instance of robust maternal care. Here, the neural circuits regulating maternal behavior must interact intimately with the neural circuits regulating feeding to allow voluntary starvation in order not to eat the young despite significant loss of body mass. The proposed experiments will be conducted at Reed College & Louisiana State University, providing research and exchange opportunities between undergraduates at a top liberal arts institution and both undergraduate and graduate students from an EPSCoR institution (LSU). Understanding the degree to which mechanisms and brain regions for feeding have been co-opted for maternal care will inform our general understanding of the evolution of this important adaptive social behavior. In addition to addressing the evolution of maternal care, this research may impact human health research related to metabolic and feeding disorders as it may uncover novel mechanisms that allow decoupling of these circuits.

This collaborative research project aims to understand the molecular and physiological mechanisms that underlie the behavioral switch from self-promoting behavior to offspring-promoting behavior that is required for robust maternal care. Astatotilapia burtoni has been a long standing model for sociogenomics and integrative animal behavior. Using immunohistochemistry, researchers and their students will quantify immediate-early gene expression in specific neuronal types across the "maternal brain" as well as assay cell types for changes in size or number. Using transriptomic approaches, they will quantify gene expression differences in candidate brain nuclei as well as peripheral signaling systems. Finally, in vivo neural recordings from neurons in the preoptic area will be used to determine physiological sensitivity to egg/fry versus food-related stimuli during different stages of maternal care. Fully describing the cichlid maternal brain as it interacts with feeding regulation is the long term collaborative agenda of the two researchers and allows them to capitalize on the synergy of simultaneously describing gene expression and functional studies. Students from Reed College and Louisiana State University will be involved in all aspects of this research. This project includes a math-biology collaboration to have students develop R scripts to interrogate similarity and differences between different gene expression networks in the different brain regions and different female groups. All resulting scripts and algorithms will be hosted online, disseminated through publication and presented by students at scientific conferences.

por.por_cntn:
For many animals, maternal care is an essential social behavior that must be balanced against competing behavioral interests such as feeding and mating. While the neural circuits regulating maternal behaviors are well studied in several mammalian systems, little is known about whether similar neural circuits exist in other vertebrates, which limits our understanding of how the maternal brain evolved. This collaborative project used an integrative approach at multiple levels of biological organization to further our understanding of how the neural circuits regulating often conflicting behaviors related to feeding and maternal care might be shared or distinct. Experiments were performed in an African cichlid fish, in which females cycle between a feeding reproductive gravid state and a starvation mouthbrooding state. Which brain regions are involved in allowing females to switch between these drastically different reproductive and energetic states, however, remained unexplored. Our analysis of neural activation patterns in brooding, fed, and starved groups of females identified key brain regions involved in both the starvation aspect of mouthbrooding, as well as the maternal aspect of brooding. Our data also provided support for shared and overlapping circuitry between feeding/energetics and parental care, consistent with that found in other vertebrates. These neural activation patterns are also useful for better resolving brain homologies between fishes and mammals. Our work also identified key players involved in the regulation of feeding/energetics and maternal care circuits in the brain, including galanin, vasotocin, NPY, AgRP, POMC, and nesfatin. Because mouthbrooding females also make decisions on whether to care for or consume their own young, we also compared neural activation patterns in mouthbrooding, maternal care, and infanticide females to examine the brain regions involved in the transition from brood care to fry care, as well as those regions involved in the case where females decide to consume their own young (infanticide). Results of this work show that females performing infanticide have different overall neural activation patterns across the brain than females performing maternal behaviors. Because infanticide is widespread across the animal kingdom, this provides important comparative data towards understanding how the brain is involved in the decision to provide care vs. consume young.

Overall, results of this work advance our current understanding of how the brain regulates trade-offs between maternal care and feeding/energetics, which is crucial for offspring survival and persistence of parental species in a changing world. Further, it provides important comparative data in a fish species to better understand the evolution of parental care and the neural mechanisms involved to help advance the field. This project also provided research and training opportunities for many women and undergraduate and graduate students from underrepresented groups in an EPSCoR jurisdiction, generated science web-resources for the public and other research scientists, and was widely disseminated via publications, presentations, and outreach events.
